justification: Mandatory requirement applied to new buildings and certain alterations under DOB permitting; not limited to optional program universe.
Trigger is text-scoreable: projects filed on or after effective date and involving new buildings or replacement of all exterior glazing.
Explicit regulated vertical zone up to 75 feet above grade for bird-friendly materials requirements.
Uses an operational technical standard for bird-friendly materials implemented through DOB guidance.
Defines hazards such as fly-through conditions and bird hazard installations to operationalize compliance.
No location or proximity-based hazard logic; compliance is structured primarily around a height-based zone.
Guidance operationalizes bird-friendly materials but does not enumerate a closed list of acceptable treatments.
No lighting requirements are stated in Local Law 15 or associated DOB guidance.
Compliance is tied to DOB plan and permit review with required documentation demonstrating bird-friendly materials.
Clear permit-based review gate where compliance is checked during DOB permitting and filings.
Enforcement occurs through permit approval and violation architecture rather than an explicit penalty schedule within the section.
Narrow applicability and trigger structure function as implicit carveouts but explicit broad waivers are not central.
Applies only to a limited universe of projects subject to DPD review or city assistance pathways.
Trigger is defined by SDP applicability categories rather than universal construction thresholds.
Bird protection strategies are not tied to a defined height band or collision-risk zone.
Provides strategy options without a single quantified universal performance standard.
Does not rely on codified architectural hazard definitions as a core compliance driver.
No explicit location-based hazard designation is required for bird protection strategy selection.
Bird protection is addressed through basic and enhanced strategy options rather than codified treatment rules.
Lighting considerations appear as part of broader sustainability strategies rather than mandatory bird-specific restrictions.
SDP requires documentation and review for compliance and includes audit mechanisms within the SDP process.
Review gate exists through SDP eligibility and compliance but is program-based rather than a citywide permit mandate.
Enforcement relies on eligibility and approval gatekeeping rather than standalone citywide code penalties.
Menu-based compliance structure creates functional carveouts because projects may satisfy requirements through alternative strategies.
